fields.description: Restaurants are a vital part of many communities’ economic bases and draw visitors from around the Metro Boston region. Local restaurants rather than chain establishments dominate the market in these municipalities. Partnering with local restaurants to offer healthier options in a healthy dining program will improve nutrition for residents and visitors. By September 29, 2014, Everett will increase the number of full service restaurants that offer and promote healthier dining options (including fresh fruits and vegetables, whole grains, lower sodium/no salt added meals, smaller portions) through an established healthy dining program. This strategy will improve residents’ access to healthy, affordable fresh fruits and vegetables, increasing the number of people who consume the recommended amount of produce each day.
fields.title: Healthy Dining Program

fields.description: Corner stores and other small neighborhood markets are important shopping destinations for many residents particularly for residents unable to travel to grocery stores and farmers markets. The goal of this initiative is to add healthier options to these smaller markets. The goal of this initiative by September 29, 2014,is to increase the number of convenience stores (as defined by Standard Industry Classification Codes) within Everett that will offer and promote healthier food and beverages (including fresh fruits and vegetables, whole grain products, lower sodium options, and low fat dairy) through an established healthy neighborhood market program. This strategy will improve residents’ access to healthy, affordable fresh fruits and vegetables, increasing the number of people who consume the recommended amount of produce each day.
fields.title: Healthy Corner Stores Initiative

fields.description: The goal of this initiative is to identify potential walking routes that would connect neighborhoods with the lower Mystic River and its tributaries to create new opportunities for the community to access and enjoy the Mystic River. Everett will work to establish walking routes to the Mystic River and biking routes to the coast. There is ongoing work with MAPC and Bike to the Seas on identifying and promoting Walk to the River and Bike to Sea routes. The Northern Strand Community Trail Cleanup took place on May 5, 2012.
fields.title: Walking Routes to the Mystic River

fields.description: The goal of this initiative is to improve nutritional quality of foods and beverages served or available in schools consistent with the Massachusetts School Nutrition Standards based on the Institute of Medicine’s Nutrition Standards for Foods in Schools. By September 29, 2016, Everett will increase the number of school districts that have implemented nutritional guidelines that exceed the basic MDPH guidelines. This strategy will improve nutrition for the children enrolled in the Everett schools.
fields.title: School Nutrition

fields.description: Safe routes to School programs promote healthy alternative ways for children to get to and from school. Implementation of a safe routes to school program provides more opportunities for children to walk and cycle more to improve their physical health. By September 29, 2014, Everett will increase the number of schools in Everett with an active safe routes to school program. Waltham currently has three active Safe Routes to School programs and looks to expand this to five more elementary schools.
fields.title: Increasing the Number of Schools with an Active Safe Routes to School Program

fields.description: Farmers markets that are located in convenient areas and that feature culturally appropriate options can promote better nutrition for lower income and urban residents in these communities. The goal of this initiative is to reduce barriers to access and increase utilization of farmer’s markets for low income residents. By September 29, 2014, Everett will increase the number of purchases by participants of SNAP and Massachusetts Farmers Market Coupons at farmer’s markets. This strategy will improve residents’ access to healthy, affordable fresh fruits and vegetables, increasing the number of people who consume the recommended amount of produce each day. (Image credit)
fields.title: Increasing SNAP Purchases at Farmers Markets

fields.description: Many residents currently access municipal buildings for services, recreation, and other uses. Changes to municipal vending procurement policies in these municipalities, which struggle with high rates of obesity and hypertension, will reduce exposure for all residents to unhealthy foods. By September 30, 2014, Everett will increase the number of vending machines in government buildings that will be stocked with 100% healthy beverage options (water, sparkling water, 100% fruit juice in small portions) and healthy, lower sodium food options. This strategy will improve residents’ access to healthy, affordable fresh fruits and vegetables, increasing the number of people who consume the recommended amount of produce each day.
fields.title: Healthy Vending Machines in Municipal Buildings

fields.description: Everett's Mass in Motion program will meet with municipal leaders and Everett Public Schools Superintendent about expanding community recreational facilities to include neighborhood schools.
fields.title: Increase Joint Use Agreements that Gives Schools Access to City Buildings

fields.description: Establishing community design standards or “complete streets” can make streets safe for all users, including pedestrians, bicyclists and users of public transit. The goal of this initiative, by September 29, 2014, is to develop “Complete Streets” guidelines. This strategy will improve the health of all with a particular benefit to carless residents who are disproportionately low income.
fields.title: Complete Streets Guidelines

fields.description:
Increasing healthy and safe physical environments through the implementation a youth community safety audit using the PhotoVoice technique, a process in which community members use pictures and/or video to capture elements of the environment and experience to share with others.

PhotoVoice
fields.title: Community Empowerment for Healthy Environments

fields.description:
Increasing healthy and safe physical environments through the implementation a youth community safety audit using the PhotoVoice technique, a process in which community members use pictures and video to capture and share with others their experience of the urban environment.

PhotoVoice

This summer, eleven Cambridge youth ages 15-23 took part in a Community Safety Photovoice project facilitated by the Cambridge Police Department, which highlighted aspects of the community that made the youth action researchers feel safe or unsafe. They presented their findings to City Official on September 10, 2012 in the Sullivan Chambers at Cambridge City Hall.  The six themes that the youth presented were: city maintenance, residential maintenance, health, crime, homelessness, and positive prevention.

Cambridge Police on Facebook

Cambride News
fields.title: Community Empowerment for Healthy Environments

Hubway is a bike sharing system that offers residents an accessible option and opportunity to engage in physical activity. The Hubway program will be expanded into Somerville at the end of the summer of 2012.

Hubway

fields.description: The Boston Public Health Commission, the country’s oldest health department, is an independent public agency providing a wide range of health services and programs. Public service and access to quality health care are the cornerstones of our mission - to protect, preserve, and promote the health and well-being of all Boston residents, particularly those who are most vulnerable. Visit the BPH website to learn more about the more than 40 programs they operate in Boston.
fields.title: Boston Public Health Commission

The new walking routes provide additional opportunities for residents to engage in physical activity. Malden will work to establish walking routes to the Mystic River and biking routes to the coast. The photo is from a river walk event held in April 2012, view the complete set of photos from the event here.

fields.description: Waltham will recruit at least 8 Food and Fitness Policy council members through one-on-one meetings, ensuring targeted recruitment efforts of low-income populations, youth and elders, and organizations serving low income populations, youth and elders. In the process, Waltham will build community understanding and support for the work of Food and Fitness Policy Council through various communications channels; one television feature and at least three print media stories earned.
fields.title: Food and Fitness Policy Council

fields.description:
The Community Transformation Grant (CTG) is a five year $1.6 million grant awarded by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). It is designed to help communities tackle the root causes of chronic disease such as smoking, poor diet and lack of physical activity, with an additional focus on reducing health disparities among lower-income Americans, racial and ethnic minorities, and other underserved populations that often have higher rates of disease. As a Community Transformation Grantee, Middlesex County will demonstrate improvements in body mass index, nutrition, physical activity, tobacco control, and emotional well-being. The CTG funding expands the Mass in Motion program, Massachusetts’ state-wide obesity prevention initiative, to 12 communities within Middlesex County.

MAPC’s Community Transformation Grant Website
fields.title: Community Transformation Grant

fields.description: Many residents currently access municipal buildings for services, recreation, and other uses. Changes to municipal vending procurement policies in these municipalities, which struggle with high rates of obesity and hypertension, will reduce exposure for all residents to unhealthy foods. The goal of this initiative, by September 30, 2014, is to increase the number of vending machines in government buildings in Framingham, Hudson, and Marlborough that will be stocked with 100% healthy beverage options (water, sparkling water, 100% fruit juice in small portions) and healthy, lower sodium food options. This strategy will improve residents’ access to healthy, affordable fresh fruits and vegetables, increasing the number of people who consume the recommended amount of produce each day.
fields.title: Healthy Vending Machines in Municipal Buildings

fields.description:
With three children in college and a 50-hour work week, Mike Deprino, 54, doesn’t have extra time or money for a gym membership. “I used to go for a 30 minute walk every morning before work. Last Fall, I tripped on a huge patch of broken up concrete, and that put a stop to my workouts real quick.” Deprino, like many others in Gloucester, became well aware of Gloucester’s many missing curbs, narrow and damaged sidewalks and broken patches of concrete and asphalt.  While walking, biking and jogging are among some of the easiest ways to be active, taking a stroll along these streets just wasn’t as safe and accessible as it needed to be.

With town Mayor Kirk’s enthusiastic support, Get Fit Gloucester! Mass in Motion Project Manager Stephen Winslow, the Community Development Department, MassHighway and DPW Engineers worked together to come up with solutions for these much-needed sidewalk improvements for major streets serving low and moderate income residents.  These included new concrete sidewalks, widened sidewalks, curb repairs, re-paving, bicycle-friendly storm drain installations, and new ramps that met ADA regulations.

One of the biggest improvements includes a new sidewalk that closes the gap between Downtown Gloucester and the Riverdale neighborhood. “I’m using that sidewalk Monday through Friday now. Getting outside in the morning before work helps me clear my head and feel ready for the day. Not to mention I’m getting my workouts in again, without having to watch each and every step carefully so I don’t trip or fall.” Deprino isn’t the only one making use of these new improvements! Many Gloucester residents have been enthusiastic about the number of sidewalk improvements and are able to walk, run, or ride about the beautiful town of Gloucester much more easily!

(Personal details are illustrative.)
fields.title: Improving Gloucester's Sidewalks

fields.description:
Community leaders in Gloucester have long sought to connect the city’s waterfront promenade with the waterfront along the downtown. The Community Development office, along with local residents, developed a new Harbor Economic Development Plan in 2010. This Plan identified the need for pedestrian connections along the waterfront and between the Harbor and Downtown to connect these three sectors and improve the economic viability of Gloucester’s working waterfront. Get Fit Gloucester! (Gloucester’s Mass in Motion program) Project Manager Stephen Winslow worked with other Community Development staff to plan out the next segment of the Harborwalk. staff plotted out practical segments of the harborwalk extension and developed cost-estimates. The Seaport Advisory Council granted the City of Gloucester $500,000 to design and construct the Harbor Walk extension. The City recently hired Cambridge 7 Associates to design and build the extension by the end of 2011.

- Read more about the Harborwalk extension project (coming soon)

(Photo credit)
fields.title: Harborwalk Expansion Part of Pedestrian Improvements

fields.description: All fourth and fifth graders at Medford's Brooks Elementary School spent one month improving their fitness and having fun, by participating in the month-long Brooks Walking Challenge. The students received free pedometers, provided by Medford Health Matters and Safe Routes to Schools, to keep track of their steps for a month. They celebrated their achievement Friday morning, May 25th. The Brooks Walking Challenge is part of Walk/Ride Days, a program that celebrates and promotes the use of sustainable, active transportation in Medford and other communities. Syrah McGivern, Community Transformation Grant Coordinator for the Medford Board of Health, emceed the event. Read more about the event at Green Medford
fields.title: Elementary School Students Take Walking Challenge

fields.description:
Jamie Valdez, 38, is a working mother of two living in Fitchburg. With two active and curious boys, Joseph and Trudy, Jamie is in constant need of fun, safe places the three of them can visit to be active and outdoors.

But while Fitchburg has 39 different parks offering many activities for youth, these haven’t always been viable options for the Valdez family. Most of them remain untouched due to what many consider an unsafe image (used needles and syringes, graffiti, burnt trash cans, and isolated park areas). Safety, however, wasn’t the only issue keeping people like Jamie away. A lot of people don’t even know these parks exist. “The children living here are in desperate need of safe options for physical activity that are close to their neighborhoods,” stated AynYeagle, the Fun n’ FITchburg Mass in Motion coordinator.

Fun n’ FITchburg conducted an in-depth park assessment, and then ran a long-term media campaign, encouraging community members to learn about these parks and volunteer for an adopt-a-park program to keep the areas safe and clean. Jamie Valdez was one of the first to volunteer for the adopt-a-park program. “I wanted to help out with the community, but selfishly, I also wanted a safe place for my kids to play,” says Jamie. Since then, they’ve been catching, tagging, and Simon says-ing on the weekends and several week days after school. “Not only do I not have to worry about my kids being safe, but I also don’t have to worry that they’re spending all their free time in front of the TV and video games.”
fields.title: Pumping up Park Safety in Fitchburg

fields.description:
Launched in 2009 by the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, Mass in Motion is a state-wide obesity prevention  initiative that stresses the importance of healthy eating and physical activity. Key elements of this initiative are:

  • Mass in Motion: A Call to  Action – a Massachusetts obesity burden document.
  • Regulatory changes promoting healthy eating and physical activity, including Body Mass Index (BMI) testing of public
    school students in grades 1, 4, 7, and 10.
  • An Executive Order (EO509) by Governor Patrick which requires state agencies which provide food as part of their client and patient services to follow specific nutrition standards when purchasing and serving foods and beverages.
  • Grants to cities and towns to make wellness a priority – funding comes from five major health-funding foundations and other leading health organizations in Massachusetts.
  • The  Worksite Wellness Program, which creates environments that encourage healthy behaviors while reducing absenteeism and health insurance costs.
  • The Mass in Motion website, which features simple, cost-effective ways for residents to eat better and be more acive.
  • The MA Children at Play Initative and the 2000-Calorie Campaign, both funded by federal stimulus (ARRA) grants.
fields.title: Mass In Motion

fields.description:
The Cambridge Food and Fitness Policy Council was established in 2011 to make healthy foods and fitness opportunities available to more residents. The council, led by the Cambridge Public Health Department, represents a major step forward in creating a comprehensive approach for addressing obesity at the municipal level. It is also an opportunity for city and community partners to join together to achieve common goals—namely reducing diet-related chronic diseases and hunger.

Update

The Food and Fitness Policy Council was established and has held three meetings.  The membership includes staff from city departments, schools, community-based organizations, and members of the community.

Cambridge Food and Fitness Policy Council
fields.title: Establish a Food and Fitness Policy Council

fields.description:
Farmers markets that are located in convenient areas and that feature culturally appropriate options can promote better nutrition for lower income and urban residents in these communities. The goal of this initiative is to reduce barriers to access and increase utilization of farmer’s markets for low income residents. By September 29, 2014, Cambridge will increase the number of purchases by participants of SNAP and Massachusetts Farmers Market Coupons at farmer’s markets. This strategy will improve residents’ access to healthy, affordable fresh fruits and vegetables, increasing the number of people who consume the recommended amount of produce each day. The Cambridge Community Center successfully launched the Cambridge Winter Farmers Market, which had a successful first season (January to April 2012).

Update

Of Cambridge’s six farmers’ markets, two farmers’ markets that accept SNAP/WIC in the summer and one farmers’ market accepting in the winter.

The First Winter Farmers’ Market in Cambridge opened at the Cambridge Community Center (CCC) in January 2012 with 22 vendors drawing between 400 and 800 visitors per week. This coming winter, CCC wants to build on the market’s success by increasing outreach and advertising, including to low-income populations.  An outreach campaign is planned for this fall. Article on boston.com.

Cambridge Farmers Markets

(Image credit)
fields.title: Increasing SNAP Purchases at Farmers Markets

fields.description:
The goal of this initiative is to improve nutritional quality of foods and beverages served or available in schools consistent with the Massachusetts School Nutrition Standards based on the Institute of Medicine’s Nutrition Standards for Foods in Schools. By September 29, 2016, Melrose-Wakefield will increase the number of schools that have implemented nutritional guidelines that exceed the basic MDPH guidelines. This strategy will improve nutrition for the children enrolled in the Melrose and Wakefield school districts. The revised guidelines should have more stringent standards and/or expanded hours and settings covered by guidelines.

As of September 2012, Melrose Public Schools have implemented the nutritional guidelines throughout the district!  Thank you to Superintendent Taymore's office, Food Service Director Ken Dolce and his staff, including Dr. Heather Josephson, and the School Wellness Advisory Committee.
fields.title: School Nutrition

fields.description:
Safe Routes to School programs promote healthy alternative ways for children to get to and from school. Implementation of a safe routes to school program provides more opportunities for children to walk and cycle more to improve their physical health. The goal of this initiative, by September 29, 2014, is to increase the number of schools in Melrose, and Wakefield with an active safe routes to school program.

As of March 2012, 3/5 public elementary schools in Melrose, 4/4 elementary schools in Wakefield were enrolled and considered SRTS partners.  The middle schools and 2 Melrose elementaries were not yet enrolled.

As of May 2012, the Melrose Veterans Memorial Middle School and 2 additional elementaries became partners!

For more photos and information, visit www.MiMmelrosewakefield.com.
fields.title: Increasing the Number of Schools with an Active Safe Routes to School Program

Thanks to MiM, a “market money” system for both Melrose & Wakefield Farmers Markets has been established--both markets can now process SNAP/EBT and credit/debit.

Melrose (Sally Franks) Farmers Market is thriving at its new location at Cedar Park.  Wakefield Farmers Market won 1st place in MA in the Americal Farmland Trust Favorite Farmers Market Contest in 2012!  Both locations have been outfitted with bike racks as of September 2012.

fields.description:
The goal of this initiative is to improve nutritional quality of foods and beverages served or available in schools consistent with the Massachusetts School Nutrition Standards based on the Institute of Medicine’s Nutrition Standards for Foods in Schools. By September 29, 2016, Cambridge will increase the number of school districts that have implemented nutritional guidelines that exceed the basic Massachusetts Department of Public Health guidelines. This strategy will improve nutrition for the children enrolled in the Cambridge school districts. The revised guidelines should have more stringent standards and/or expanded hours and settings covered by guidelines. Cambridge has introduced more fresh fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and beans on public school menus and aligning menus to meet new state and federal regulations.

Cambridge Public Schools Food Initiatives
fields.title: School Nutrition

fields.description:
We live in a time when oversized portions are the norm and obesity rates are through the roof – but don’t be fooled. Not everyone has enough to eat. In Massachusetts, almost 1 in 10 households have trouble accessing healthy foods. People who don’t have easy access to healthy food are more likely to be overweight, and have a higher risk for diabetes and heart disease. With this in mind, the Franklin Mass in Motion team, Healthy Futures Franklin, dug in their heels, picked up their shovels, and decided to build a community garden. A community garden would provide Franklin with fresh and affordable healthy fruits and veggies; a way to get to know friends and neighbors; and a learning experience for families struggling with poor nutrition.

View Mass in Motion Update about Community Garden Project (coming soon)

(Image credit)
fields.title: Community Garden Expands Access to Fresh Foods

fields.description: Establishing community design standards or “complete streets” can make streets safe for all users, including pedestrians, bicyclists and users of public transit. The goal of this initiative, by September 29, 2014, is to develop “Complete Streets” guidelines. This strategy will improve the health of all residents, with a particular benefit to carless residents, who are disproportionately low income.
fields.title: Complete Streets Guidelines

fields.description:
Establishing community design standards or “complete streets” can make streets safe for all users, including pedestrians, bicyclists and users of public transit. The goal of this initiative, by September 29, 2014, is to develop “Complete Streets” guidelines. This strategy will improve the health of all residents in these municipalities (273,000), with a particular benefit to carless residents (30,400), who are disproportionately low income

Cambridge has been using Complete Streets practices for a number of years. Cambridge has a process in place that bike lanes or cycle tracks are installed whenever roads are resurfaced, provided there is sufficient space. One current project is the Western Avenue Redesign. See more information.
fields.title: Complete Streets Guidelines

fields.description: Many residents currently access municipal buildings for services, recreation, and other uses. Changes to municipal vending procurement policies in these municipalities, which struggle with high rates of obesity and hypertension, will reduce exposure for all residents to unhealthy foods. The goal of this initiative, by September 30, 2014, is to increase the number of vending machines in government buildings in Framingham, Hudson, and Marlborough that will be stocked with 100% healthy beverage options (water, sparkling water, 100% fruit juice in small portions) and healthy, lower sodium food options. This strategy will improve residents’ access to healthy, affordable fresh fruits and vegetables, increasing the number of people who consume the recommended amount of produce each day.
fields.title: Healthy Vending Machines in Municipal Buildings

fields.description: Establishing community design standards or “complete streets” can make streets safe for all users, including pedestrians, bicyclists and users of public transit. The goal of this initiative, by September 29, 2014, is to develop “Complete Streets” guidelines. This strategy will improve the health of all residents, with a particular benefit to carless residents, who are disproportionately low income.
fields.title: Complete Streets Guidelines

fields.description: Safe routes to School programs promote healthy alternative ways for children to get to and from school. Implementation of a safe routes to school program provides more opportunities for children to walk and cycle more to improve their physical health. The goal of this initiative, by September 29, 2014, is to increase the number of schools in Malden with an active safe routes to school program. Malden currently has four active Safe Routes to School programs and looks to expand this to one more elementary school.
fields.title: Increasing the Number of Schools with an Active Safe Routes to School Program

fields.description: Malden will increase awareness of healthy zoning regulations that are legally sound, beneficial to the business community and limit the density of fast food and other outlets featuring high calorie, high sodium, and low nutrition food via zoning that regulates the number of fast food outlets in a given area.
fields.title: Increase Awareness of Healthy Zoning Regulations

fields.title: Complete Streets Guidelines

fields.description:
Hubway, is a bike sharing system that offers residents an accessible option and opportunity to engage in physical activity .Cambridge has joined the Hubway bike share program and bike stations will be installed during summer 2012.

Update

The kickoff event for the Hubway expansion took place on August 8, 2012.  There are currently 11 of the 24 stations installed.

Hubway
fields.title: Hubway Expansion
